But when you start investing, you're prone to letting your emotions take over." data-c-credit="USA TODAY, Wochit"></div></aside><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>The financial services industry is duping the American public with its pro-environment, sustainable investing practices. This multitrillion dollar arena of socially conscious investing is being presented as something it's not. In essence, Wall Street is greenwashing the economic system and, in the process, creating a deadly distraction. I should know; I was at the heart of it.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>As the<a href=https://www.blackrock.com/institutions/en-us/biographies/tariq-fancy target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a> former chief investment officer of Sustainable Investing</a> at BlackRock, the <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/14/investing/blackrock-earnings-ishares-etfs/index.html#:~:text=BlackRock%20(BLK)%2C%20the%20world's,from%20the%20end%20of%202019." target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>largest asset manager in the world with $8.7 trillion in assets</a>, I <a href="https://reporting.unpri.org/Download.aspx?id=603b72b5-7383-4ed6-a1d7-a59d4e1c2d24" target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>led the charge</a> to incorporate environmental, social and governance (ESG) into our global investments. In fact, our messaging helped mainstream the concept that pursuing social good was also good for the bottom line. Sadly, that's all it is, a hopeful idea. In truth, sustainable investing boils down to little more than marketing hype, PR spin and disingenuous promises from the investment community.</p><aside aria-label=advertisement class="gnt_m gnt_x gnt_x__lbl gnt_x__al"><div data-g-r=lazy data-gl-method=lazyLoadX id=~ad-slot-7103-usatoday-native-article_link-opinion-2 class="gnt_x_sl gnt_x_al"></div></aside><h2 class=gnt_ar_b_h2>SEC looking to 'proactively identify ESG-related misconduct'</h2><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>In many instances across the industry, existing mutual funds are cynically rebranded as “green” — with no discernible change to the fund itself or its underlying strategies — simply for the <a href=https://www.wsj.com/articles/as-funds-jump-on-the-sustainable-bandwagon-regulators-raise-concerns-11586103274 target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>sake of appearances and marketing purposes</a>. In <a href=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-25/record-flows-pour-into-esg-funds-as-their-wokeness-is-debated target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>other cases</a>, ESG products contain irresponsible companies such as petroleum majors and other large polluters like “fast fashion” manufacturing to boost the fund's performance. There are even portfolio managers who actively mine ESG data to bet against environmentally responsible companies in the name of profit, a short-selling strategy. Risk managers are focused on protecting their investment portfolios from potential damages done by a worsening climate rather than helping prevent that damage from occurring in the first place.</p><aside aria-label=advertisement class="gnt_m gnt_x gnt_x__lbl gnt_x__al"><div data-g-r=lazy data-gl-method=lazyLoadX id=~ad-slot-7103-usatoday-native-article_link-opinion-3 class="gnt_x_sl gnt_x_al"></div></aside><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>As disheartening as this reality is, claiming to be environmentally responsible is profitable. Last year alone, ESG mutual funds and exchange-traded funds <a href=https://www.blackrock.com/corporate/investor-relations/larry-fink-ceo-letter target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>nearly doubled</a>. The investment community understandably reacted to this with cheers. But those cheers were only for fund managers and their bottom lines. No matter what they tout as green investing, portfolio managers are legally bound (as well as financially incentivized) <a href=https://www.blackrock.com/corporate/investor-relations/larry-fink-ceo-letter target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>to do nothing that compromises profits</a>. To advance real change in the environment simply doesn't yield the same return.</p><figure class="gnt_em gnt_em_img"><img class=gnt_em_img_i style=height:425px data-g-r=lazy data-gl-src="https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2021/03/11/USAT/b2fabdbd-5716-4b65-bc82-63a16a1e1d0f-AFP_AFP_93W2J4.jpg?width=660&height=425&fit=crop&format=pjpg&auto=webp" data-gl-srcset="https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2021/03/11/USAT/b2fabdbd-5716-4b65-bc82-63a16a1e1d0f-AFP_AFP_93W2J4.jpg?width=1320&height=850&fit=crop&format=pjpg&auto=webp 2x" decoding=async alt="Wall Street on Feb. 8, 2021, in New York City."/><div class="gnt_em_img_ccw gnt_em_img_ccw__cap gnt_em_img_ccw__crd" data-c-caption="Wall Street on Feb. 8, 2021, in New York City." data-c-credit="Kena Betancur/AFP Via Getty Images"></div></figure><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>In early March, my sentiments were echoed by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), which announced it was creating a <a href=https://www.sec.gov/news/press-release/2021-42 target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>Climate and ESG Task Force</a> to “proactively identify ESG-related misconduct” such as inaccurate or incomplete disclosures by funds and companies — an unprecedented move that suggests there might be abuses that have gone unaddressed. </p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p><em><strong class=gnt_ar_b_al>Cuomo moment:</strong><a href=/story/opinion/voices/2021/03/11/andrew-cuomo-sexual-harassment-albany-workplace-safety-column/6940985002/ target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>We work in New York government. Sexual harassment in Albany is an open secret.</a></em></p><aside class="gnt_em gnt_em_anc" id=gnt_atomsnc data-g-r=lazy data-gl-method=loadAnc aria-label="Newsletter signup form"></aside><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>Ironically, the COVID-19 pandemic has forced us to learn some painful lessons. The initial response of rosy forecasts, loose half-measures and group denial boosted morale, but it also lulled the public into a false sense of security that prolonged and worsened the crisis.</p><h2 class=gnt_ar_b_h2>We need to fix the system before disaster strikes</h2><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>While how we fight a pandemic and climate change are very different, one aspect is clear. Both threats can only be won through the combined efforts of science and policy. In response to the pandemic, we’ve learned that only top-down government action, such as forcing the closure of high-risk venues and mandating masks indoors, makes a real difference. A “free market” will not correct itself or fix the problem by its own accord.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>Imagine the planet is a cancer patient, and climate change is the cancer. Wall Street is prescribing wheatgrass: A well-marketed, profitable idea that has no chance of curing or even slowing down the cancer. In this scenario, wheatgrass is the deadly distraction, misleading the public and delaying lifesaving measures like chemotherapy. But like giving false hope to unproven cures in the midst of a pandemic, the consequences of such irresponsibility are all too obvious. And motivation for why the industry continues to greenwash is all too obvious.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p><em><strong class=gnt_ar_b_al>COVID:</strong><a href=/story/opinion/voices/2021/03/10/covid-19-wear-masks-get-vaccine-protect-frontline-troops-column/4643472001/ target=_blank rel=noopener data-t-l=":b|e|inline click|${u}" class=gnt_ar_b_a>Support frontline COVID troops. Even as restrictions lift, say yes to masks, vaccines and unity.</a></em></p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>When I left the industry in late 2019, due to family business obligations following the passing of my father-in-law, I was frustrated by the lack of any real change. But I took some comfort in believing that if we weren’t doing as much as we could, at least we weren’t doing any harm. Since my departure, I have had a lot of time to think about this issue, and I’ve reassessed my opinion. I believe we are doing irreversible harm by stalling and greenwashing. And all in the name of profits.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p>We’re running out of time and need to accept the truth: To fix our system and curb a growing disaster, we need government to fix the rules.</p><p class=gnt_ar_b_p><em>Tariq Fancy is the former chief investment officer for Sustainable Investing at BlackRock.</em></p><aside class="gnt_em gnt_em_hf" data-g-r=lazy data-gl-type=method readabilityObject.title: Financial world greenwashing the public with deadly distraction in sustainable investing practices
readabilityObject.content:
The financial services industry is duping the American public with its pro-environment, sustainable investing practices. This multitrillion dollar arena of socially conscious investing is being presented as something it's not. In essence, Wall Street is greenwashing the economic system and, in the process, creating a deadly distraction. I should know; I was at the heart of it.

As the former chief investment officer of Sustainable Investing at BlackRock, the largest asset manager in the world with $8.7 trillion in assets, I led the charge to incorporate environmental, social and governance (ESG) into our global investments. In fact, our messaging helped mainstream the concept that pursuing social good was also good for the bottom line. Sadly, that's all it is, a hopeful idea. In truth, sustainable investing boils down to little more than marketing hype, PR spin and disingenuous promises from the investment community.

SEC looking to 'proactively identify ESG-related misconduct'

In many instances across the industry, existing mutual funds are cynically rebranded as “green” — with no discernible change to the fund itself or its underlying strategies — simply for the sake of appearances and marketing purposes. In other cases, ESG products contain irresponsible companies such as petroleum majors and other large polluters like “fast fashion” manufacturing to boost the fund's performance. There are even portfolio managers who actively mine ESG data to bet against environmentally responsible companies in the name of profit, a short-selling strategy. Risk managers are focused on protecting their investment portfolios from potential damages done by a worsening climate rather than helping prevent that damage from occurring in the first place.

As disheartening as this reality is, claiming to be environmentally responsible is profitable. Last year alone, ESG mutual funds and exchange-traded funds nearly doubled. The investment community understandably reacted to this with cheers. But those cheers were only for fund managers and their bottom lines. No matter what they tout as green investing, portfolio managers are legally bound (as well as financially incentivized) to do nothing that compromises profits. To advance real change in the environment simply doesn't yield the same return.

In early March, my sentiments were echoed by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), which announced it was creating a Climate and ESG Task Force to “proactively identify ESG-related misconduct” such as inaccurate or incomplete disclosures by funds and companies — an unprecedented move that suggests there might be abuses that have gone unaddressed. 

Cuomo moment:We work in New York government. Sexual harassment in Albany is an open secret.

Ironically, the COVID-19 pandemic has forced us to learn some painful lessons. The initial response of rosy forecasts, loose half-measures and group denial boosted morale, but it also lulled the public into a false sense of security that prolonged and worsened the crisis.

We need to fix the system before disaster strikes

While how we fight a pandemic and climate change are very different, one aspect is clear. Both threats can only be won through the combined efforts of science and policy. In response to the pandemic, we’ve learned that only top-down government action, such as forcing the closure of high-risk venues and mandating masks indoors, makes a real difference. A “free market” will not correct itself or fix the problem by its own accord.

Imagine the planet is a cancer patient, and climate change is the cancer. Wall Street is prescribing wheatgrass: A well-marketed, profitable idea that has no chance of curing or even slowing down the cancer. In this scenario, wheatgrass is the deadly distraction, misleading the public and delaying lifesaving measures like chemotherapy. But like giving false hope to unproven cures in the midst of a pandemic, the consequences of such irresponsibility are all too obvious. And motivation for why the industry continues to greenwash is all too obvious.

COVID:Support frontline COVID troops. Even as restrictions lift, say yes to masks, vaccines and unity.

When I left the industry in late 2019, due to family business obligations following the passing of my father-in-law, I was frustrated by the lack of any real change. But I took some comfort in believing that if we weren’t doing as much as we could, at least we weren’t doing any harm. Since my departure, I have had a lot of time to think about this issue, and I’ve reassessed my opinion. I believe we are doing irreversible harm by stalling and greenwashing. And all in the name of profits.

We’re running out of time and need to accept the truth: To fix our system and curb a growing disaster, we need government to fix the rules.

Tariq Fancy is the former chief investment officer for Sustainable Investing at BlackRock.
